detailed_report.document_title: Silent Compromise: The LandFall Spyware Operation Against Samsung Galaxy Devices

blocks.title: Executive Summary
blocks.content:
A targeted surveillance campaign using the LandFall spyware exploited a zero-day vulnerability (CVE-2025-21042) in Samsung Galaxy smartphones from July 2024 to April 2025. Attackers delivered the exploit via malicious DNG image files sent on WhatsApp, enabling zero-click arbitrary code execution on Galaxy S22, S23, S24, Z Fold 4, and Z Flip 4 devices. Once activated, LandFall manipulated SELinux policies for deep persistence and exfiltrated sensitive user data including microphone, call audio, location, photos, SMS, and browsing history. The operation focused on precision attacks against individuals predominantly in Iraq, Iran, Turkey, and Morocco, with infrastructure and tradecraft echoing those of recognized commercial surveillance vendors like Stealth Falcon. No attacker has been conclusively identified, but the campaign’s technical sophistication, narrow targeting, and extended undetected run mark it as a strategic threat to mobile device integrity.

**Key Findings:**

- **Vector / Entry Point:** Zero-click delivery of malicious DNG images via WhatsApp, secretly exploiting Samsung’s image processing library.
- **Impact:** Full device surveillance including call and microphone recording, location tracking, photos, contacts, SMS, and browsing history exfiltration.
- **Actor / Attribution:** Precise links are unconfirmed; infrastructure and TTPs share notable resemblance to Stealth Falcon, with some loader similarities to NSO Group.
- **Technique / Innovation:** Use of malformed DNG files embedding ZIP archives as a zero-click exploit chain, SELinux policy subversion for root-level access, and robust evasion mechanisms.
- **Relevance:** Demonstrates rising exploitation of media parsing flaws in mobile platforms and the reach of advanced commercial spyware through everyday apps.

items.value: Unattributed (infrastructure and tooling overlap with Stealth Falcon; some naming echoes NSO Group conventions)

Likely a private-sector offensive actor (PSOA) or commercial surveillance vendor conducting targeted espionage in the Middle East. The campaign’s selectivity and sophistication indicate a well-resourced organization rather than criminal malware operators. While infrastructure shares patterns with Stealth Falcon, and loader design resembles tools from the NSO Group, no definitive link has been publicized to date[1][4][6][10][11].

blocks.title: LandFall Spyware Tools and Methods
blocks.content:
- Primary payload is the LandFall spyware, delivered as part of a modular loader framework (notably, binaries b.so and l.so).
- The exploit leverages CVE-2025-21042, a critical out-of-bounds write in Samsung’s libimagecodec.quram.so, to achieve zero-click code execution when a DNG image is received and processed[7][9][10].
- Malicious DNG files append a ZIP-encoded payload containing Android shared objects for the loader (initialization), SELinux policy manipulation (for root/persistence), and additional surveillance modules.
- Once resident, LandFall manipulates SELinux, providing the spyware broad system privileges and persistence even after reboot[1][4][6].
- The implant fingerprints devices (collecting IMEI/IMSI/SIM/app lists) and initiates surveillance: recording microphone/calls, logging location, accessing contacts, SMS, files, and browsing history.
- Exfiltrated data and C2 traffic are concealed via HTTPS with evasion features including debugger detection, certificate pinning, and redundancy through multiple servers[1][6][10][11].
- Tools and infrastructure closely mirror commercial spyware TTPs; notable parallels in loader design and communications exist with NSO/Stealth Falcon, but with unique DNG/ZIP exploit innovation[1][4][6].

blocks.title: Vulnerabilities Exploited
blocks.content:
- **CVE-2025-21042**: Critical out-of-bounds write in libimagecodec.quram.so (Samsung’s Android image processing library). Allows remote, unauthenticated code execution by sending a single crafted DNG image file[7][9].
    - Severity: CVSS 9.8 (Critical).
    - Affects: Samsung Galaxy S22, S23, S24, Z Fold 4, Z Flip 4, Android 13–16 prior to April 2025 patch[6][7].
- Exploitation chain combines:
    - Malformed DNG files and appended ZIP for payload delivery
    - Exploitation of zero-click image parsing (no user interaction)[1][4][6].
    - SELinux policy manipulation for elevation/persistence (via l.so embedded in ZIP archive)[1][6][10].

attack_chain.action: Malformed DNG image file with appended ZIP payload is sent over WhatsApp to victim device (zero-click).
Vulnerable Samsung image library processes the image upon receiving message, triggering CVE-2025-21042 and launching the payload silently.
Embedded ZIP archive is extracted; loader (b.so) sets up environment, while SELinux manipulator (l.so) is deployed.

techniques.name: Event Triggered Execution: Security Policy Modification

attack_chain.action: l.so disables or relaxes SELinux enforcement, securing root-level/system-wide access and guaranteed spyware persistence.

Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify System Defense Tools

attack_chain.action: LandFall engages full surveillance: microphone, call audio, photos, SMS, files, contacts, location, browsing activity.
Communication with C2 via HTTPS for operator instructions and data exfiltration; custom C2 infrastructure using evasion/counter-forensics.

blocks.title: Impact and Scope
blocks.content: LandFall’s deployment resulted in full compromise of dozens to potentially hundreds of selected Samsung Galaxy devices in Iraq, Iran, Turkey, and Morocco during the campaign’s undetected window. Attackers gained persistent access to microphones, call audio, photos, messages, contacts, device identifiers, files, GPS and network location—all exfiltrated periodically to external servers. The operation enabled deep surveillance of targeted individuals with implications for privacy, physical security, and secondary victim exposure (through compromised communications and contacts). While mass infection was not observed, the campaign underlined the potential for supply-chain-scale abuse of ubiquitous mobile apps when combined with discrete, zero-click vulnerabilities in popular device models. Samsung issued a patch in April 2025, but exploitation persisted covertly for over nine months[1][4][6][7][10][11].

blocks.title: Analytical Summary
blocks.content: The LandFall campaign represents a benchmark in targeted mobile espionage, leveraging a previously unknown critical flaw in Samsung’s image processing stack and integrating zero-click delivery with persistent, system-level spyware. Its ability to deliver a full surveillance suite with no visible user action, survive device reboots, and evade forensic controls underscores the increasing danger posed by well-resourced commercial spyware actors exploiting platform-level media parsing bugs. While precise attribution remains unconfirmed, the operation’s technical proximity to recognized surveillance vendors heightens the risk of similar campaigns migrating to other devices and regions, particularly as mobile messaging and image sharing continue to escalate as vectors.

controls.action_title: Apply All Samsung Security Updates Immediately
controls.description: Ensure all Samsung Galaxy devices, particularly models S22, S23, S24, Z Fold 4, Z Flip 4, are updated past April 2025 SMR Release 1. This closes CVE-2025-21042 and related zero-days, removing primary exploitability.

controls.action_title: Disable Automatic Media Downloads in Messaging Apps
controls.description: In WhatsApp and similar apps, require manual confirmation for media downloads to reduce zero-click attack risk.
Activate features like Android’s "Advanced Protection" or iOS "Lockdown Mode" to limit exploit surface and execution permissions for all media and side-loaded content.

controls.action_title: Restrict App Permissions and Review Regularly
controls.description: Minimize granted permissions, especially to messaging apps and image processing components; audit device permission settings regularly.

controls.action_title: Monitor for SELinux Modifications and Unusual Device Behaviors
controls.description: Configure mobile device management (MDM) systems and endpoint security tools to detect altered SELinux policies, high-risk process activity, and unauthorized C2 traffic patterns.

controls.action_title: Educate End-Users on Targeted Messaging Threats
controls.description: Train high-risk users to recognize targeted surveillance attempts and secure device behaviors, and ensure rapid response procedures are in place for suspected compromise.
Use full-device encryption and strong device passcodes to resist post-exploit lateral movement and data extraction.

bluf_block.title: Bottom Line
bluf_block.content: A sophisticated spyware campaign, leveraging a zero-day vulnerability (CVE-2025-21042) in Samsung Galaxy devices, enabled remote, zero-click surveillance via malicious DNG images sent through WhatsApp. This capability presents a high risk to exposed organizations, particularly those with at-risk personnel operating in the Middle East, by granting attackers persistent access to sensitive data and communications. Exposed organizations should consider immediately applying all available Samsung security updates to eliminate current exploitability.

now_what_block.title: Now What
now_what_block.intro_sentence: Exposed organizations should consider the following prioritized actions to mitigate risk and strengthen mobile security posture:

action_groups.executive_summary: This group focuses on actions that close the current exploit vector and restrict attacker capability on high-risk devices.
action_items: Update all Samsung Galaxy S22, S23, S24, Z Fold 4, and Z Flip 4 devices beyond the April 2025 security release to address CVE-2025-21042 and related zero-days.
Disable automatic media downloads in WhatsApp and similar messaging applications to limit zero-click attack exposure.
Monitor for modifications to SELinux policies and for unusual device behaviors using MDM and endpoint security solutions.
Encrypt all sensitive data on mobile devices with strong device passcodes.

action_groups.executive_summary: These steps reduce long-term attack opportunities by tightening security controls and raising user awareness.
action_items: Enable advanced mobile protection features such as Android "Advanced Protection" or iOS "Lockdown Mode" to limit exposure to advanced threats.
Restrict app permissions, especially for messaging and media processing apps, and conduct regular permission reviews.
Educate high-risk users on targeted messaging threats and implement rapid response protocols for suspected compromise.

so_what_block.title: So What
so_what_block.intro_sentence: This campaign highlights significant business-level risks for organizations relying on mobile-first communications:

implications.title: Persistent Exposure of High-Value Data
implications.description: Attackers gained long-term access to audio, messages, location, and other sensitive user data on selected Samsung Galaxy devices, elevating the risk of compromise for organizations with personnel in targeted regions.

implications.title: Supply-Chain Scale App Abuse
implications.description: Exploitation of common apps like WhatsApp through zero-click vulnerabilities reveals a scalable attack surface affecting organizations dependent on consumer-grade messaging platforms.

implications.title: Advanced Commercial Spyware Threat
implications.description: The operation’s sophistication and evasion set a new standard for commercial mobile spyware, signaling the likelihood of similar approaches against other popular device platforms.

whats_next_block.title: Whats Next
whats_next_block.intro_sentence: The following are key indicators for executives to monitor as the situation evolves:

indicators.title: Adoption of Exploit Techniques by Other Actors
indicators.description: Monitor for reports of DNG parsing vulnerabilities or similar ZIP-embedded exploits used against additional devices or messaging platforms, as this would signal broader industry exposure.

indicators.title: Samsung and Messaging App Vendor Response
indicators.description: Track ongoing update rollouts, vendor advisories, and technical mitigations from Samsung and messaging app providers, as the pace and coverage of these responses will shape residual risk.

indicators.title: Emergence of Copycat or Variant Campaigns
indicators.description: Be alert for evidence of new campaigns leveraging similar SELinux manipulation or zero-click image-based exploits, as threat actors may iterate on LandFall's methodology for future attacks.
